feed.title: Stories by Muhammad Bilal on Medium
feed.description: Stories by Muhammad Bilal on Medium

items.title: Taking the Extra Mile: My In-Person Drop at Devsinc
items.author: Muhammad Bilal
items.description:
As a software developer and an ambassador of Devsinc, I’ve had the privilege of working with their incredible team, including Junaid Rehmat, the Regional Director, and Jannat Maheen, the HR Manager. So, when I had to choose a company for this “In-Person Drop” activity, Devsinc Islamabad was a natural choice.

I already knew I couldn’t just rely on being familiar with the people. This was about going the extra mile — stepping out of my comfort zone, taking a resume and cover letter in hand, and delivering them personally. It was nerve-wracking but exciting at the same time.

Preparing for the Drop

Before heading to the Devsinc office, I made sure to craft a highly personalized cover letter and resume that reflected not just my skills, but also my passion for Devsinc’s vision. I practiced my elevator pitch, honing it down to something that felt natural, not robotic.

Though I’ve visited the office before, walking in with the goal of landing an opportunity felt different. I was prepared for whatever came my way.

The Experience

When I arrived at the office, I was greeted warmly by the receptionist. I asked to meet Jannat Maheen, knowing she’d recognize me, but I didn’t want to rely on that. I mentioned I had an application I wanted to personally hand in.

After a brief wait, Jannat came to greet me with her characteristic smile. We exchanged pleasantries, and I delivered my pitch — not just about why I’m a great fit for a future role at Devsinc, but how much the company’s mission aligns with my personal values of achievement and growth. She was engaged and appreciated my effort of coming in person. After our conversation, I made sure to grab her email for follow-up.

Lessons Learned

  1. Breaking out of your comfort zone pays off. No matter how familiar I was with the team, physically handing in my resume and cover letter made the experience more meaningful and personal.
  2. Preparation is key. My research and practiced pitch made me feel confident. I didn’t just rely on knowing people there, but on the strength of my skills and the potential I bring.
  3. Follow-up matters. After the meeting, I sent a follow-up email thanking Jannat for her time and expressing my excitement about potential opportunities.

items.title: My Fundraising Journey: A Lesson in Resilience
items.author: Muhammad Bilal
items.description:
This week, I took part in a fundraising campaign for a social cause. Due to exams, I couldn’t join my group’s visits to organizations, but I collected donations independently. It was a meaningful learning experience.

The Experience of Convincing People

Convincing people to donate wasn’t just about asking — it involved sharing the impact of the cause. I reached out individually to friends and family, explaining how their contributions, big or small, could help. I found that one-on-one conversations allowed me to connect more personally with donors, which built trust and made them more likely to contribute.

Challenges and How I Overcame Them

Balancing exams with fundraising was tough. To stay on track, I set aside dedicated time for both tasks. Another challenge was dealing with hesitation from donors. Some were unsure how their contributions would make a difference, but by providing clear information and assuring them of transparency (with all receipts attached), I managed to win them over.

Building Resilience

Rejections were part of the process, but instead of feeling discouraged, I saw them as opportunities to improve my approach. This experience showed me that resilience is about persistence, adapting to setbacks, and learning from them.

Final Thoughts

Though I couldn’t fully participate with my group, I’m proud of the contributions I gathered on my own. All receipts and photos have been added to the fundraising folder, and the details are updated in the spreadsheet. Thanks to everyone who supported me on this journey!

items.title: Overcoming Procrastination: Fixing My Iron with the Pomodoro Technique
items.author: Muhammad Bilal
items.description:
Procrastination is a universal challenge, especially when it comes to tackling those seemingly mundane tasks that we keep putting off. As a software developer, I’m used to solving problems that require deep focus and attention, but when faced with a different kind of challenge — repairing my hostel iron — I decided to take on the task using the Pomodoro technique. Here’s how it went:

The Task

My iron had stopped working, and it was a growing inconvenience. Rather than procrastinate further, I picked this task as my “frog” — a task that I had been avoiding but knew needed to be done. I decided to employ the Pomodoro technique to help me focus and get it done without distractions.

Step 1: Getting Started

I set my Pomodoro timer for 25 minutes and got to work. First, I had to figure out how to open the iron without damaging it. I carefully removed the screws and pried it open, revealing a tangle of wires and components. I took a deep breath and dived in, looking for any visible faults.

Step 2: Staying Focused

Working with electronics can be daunting, especially when it involves electricity. I knew I had to stay focused, as a lapse in concentration could lead to mistakes or even injury. During each 25-minute session, I stayed committed to identifying the problem. At one point, I got distracted by thoughts of other things I needed to do, but I quickly wrote them down and got back to work.

Step 3: Breaks and Rewards

After each Pomodoro session, I took a 3–5 minute break to clear my mind, stretch, and grab a quick snack. These short breaks helped me recharge without losing momentum. After four Pomodoros, I took a longer break to rest my eyes and stretch my legs.

Step 4: Finding the Fault

With renewed focus, I returned to the task and eventually found the fault — a loose wire that was preventing the iron from heating up. I carefully reconnected it, ensuring everything was secure. With a little bit of soldering, the iron was back to normal!

Lessons Learned

  1. Was it difficult for you to maintain focus during the activity?
    Yes, it was a bit challenging to stay focused on a non-software-related task, but the Pomodoro technique helped me manage my attention span effectively.
  2. Did it help you accomplish more of the task than you expected?
    Absolutely! Not only did I manage to repair the iron, but I also learned a bit about how it works.
  3. Do you plan on doing this again regularly, and what will you do to improve the experience?
    I definitely plan to use this technique again. Next time, I’ll prepare better by having all the tools ready beforehand and perhaps adding some background music to enhance focus.

Conclusion

The Pomodoro technique proved to be an effective strategy to overcome procrastination, even for unexpected tasks like fixing an iron. It helped me stay on track, maintain focus, and ultimately accomplish more than I initially set out to do. If you’re struggling with procrastination, I highly recommend giving it a try!

items.title: My #JustStart Journey: Writing a Research Paper on Route Optimization
items.author: Muhammad Bilal
items.description:
Project/Goal:
I’ve embarked on an exciting journey to write and publish a Research Paper focused on Route Optimization, particularly for the Islamabad network. This goal is closely tied to my ongoing work on optimizing the public transport network in Islamabad, and publishing my findings is a crucial step in contributing to this field.

Why This Goal?
The importance of efficient public transport cannot be overstated, especially in rapidly growing urban areas like Islamabad. My work on route optimization aims to improve the public transport network, making it more efficient and accessible. To make a meaningful impact and share my findings with the broader community, publishing a research paper is essential. This will not only contribute to the academic world but also provide practical insights that can be implemented in real-world scenarios.

Challenges Faced:
As someone new to research, I’ve encountered several challenges, primarily in understanding how to conduct research and write academic papers. The process of identifying a research question, structuring a paper, and ensuring that it meets academic standards has been quite daunting.

Fortunately, our project investigator, Professor Dr. Muhammad Zaman, recognized this challenge and organized a workshop to help us.

The workshop provided much-needed clarity on the basics of research writing. With this newfound understanding, I’ve been able to formulate my research question and decide on the title for my paper.

Next Steps:
With the foundational work done, I’m now focusing on writing the introduction and background sections of my paper. This week, I’ve dedicated time to studying how research papers are written and refining my research question. In the upcoming weeks, I plan to dive into the core of my research, developing the implementation section that will showcase my findings.

Conclusion:
The journey of writing my first research paper has been challenging yet rewarding. With the support of my mentor and the knowledge gained from the workshop, I’m confident in my ability to complete this project. This experience has taught me the importance of just starting, even when the task seems overwhelming. I’m excited to see where this journey takes me and how my work will contribute to the field of route optimization.

items.title: A Journey Through Quaid-i-Azam University: Unveiling Hidden Issues
items.author: Muhammad Bilal
items.description:
As the sun rises over my university, I embark on a familiar journey from the hostel — my second home — to the Socialogy department where I spend most of my day. With my smartphone in hand, I set out to capture the essence of my daily route, but little did I know that this simple task would reveal a myriad of issues that need attention.

Open Washroom Doors

At the department, the sight of open washroom doors greets me. The unpleasant smell escapes into the corridors, highlighting a need for better hygiene and privacy.

Holes and Gaps in the Roads

The campus roads, marked by holes and gaps, become treacerous during rainy days. These hazards pose a significant risk to students and staff.

Improper Maintenance of Infrastructure

Buildings with cracked walls and faded paint reveal the neglect of proper infrastructure maintenance. It’s disheartening to see the once-vibrant campus deteriorating. Additionally, many of the fountains that used to be a charming feature of the campus are now non-functional, further contributing to the campus’s neglected appearance.

Lack of Parking Facilities

The absence of designated parking spots forces people to park haphazardly, creating chaos and inconvenience for everyone on campus.

Overgrown Grass and Trees

Approaching the central library, I encounter overgrown grass and trees. What should be a serene environment now feels like a neglected jungle, with potential hazards like bugs and snakes.

Garbage and Litter

Scattered garbage and litter detract from the natural beauty of the campus, making it look unkempt and neglected.

Open Generators

The noise from open generators disrupts the quiet atmosphere needed for studying in the library, contributing to noise pollution.

Absence of Stairs

In the transportation unit, the lack of stairs complicates access for people with physical disabilities, highlighting a need for better infrastructure planning.

Benches in Raw Sunligh

Benches placed in direct sunlight are uncomfortable and unusable during the day, leaving students without a proper place to relax between classes.

Broken Footpaths

Broken footpaths make walking a challenge, affecting the safety and comfort of everyone navigating the campus.

No Security at University Gates

The lack of security at the university gates allows anyone to enter the premises without checks, raising serious safety concerns.

Tilted Benches and Poor-Quality Tables

Returning to the hostel, I find tilted benches and poor-quality tables that provide a less-than-ideal environment for outdoor study sessions.

Through this journey, my university’s hidden issues have come to light, captured through the lens of my camera. These problems, though varied, share a common theme: they hinder the experience and safety of the students and staff who call this place their second home.

As I compile these photos, I realize the importance of addressing these issues — not just for aesthetic reasons, but for the well-being and comfort of everyone on campus. Our university deserves better, and it is up to us to advocate for the changes that will make it a safer, more welcoming place for all.
